summary.seg: The manuscript contains two Greek military treatises, Onasander's Strategicus, on generalship, and Aelian's Tactics.

The codex is composite: it is formed by two main parts written around 1569 (parts I and IV), containing the two main texts, and three quires (parts II, III, V), all made up of the same paper, which were added not much later to restore the first text, and add some brief excerpts.

The main part of the manuscript (parts I and IV) was written by the Greek scribe Angelos Bergikios (16th c., first quarter-1569). Born in Crete, from 1539 he worked in Paris, where he was appointed by the king of France Francis I (1494-1547) as scriptor of the Royal Library of Fontainebleau. Bergikios' script was used as model for the grecs du roi typeface designed by Claude Garamond. The scribe, who copied these texts several times (see A. Dain, Les manuscrits d'Onésandros, Paris 1930 and A. Dain, Histoire du texte d'Élien le Tacticien, Paris 1946), wrote a colophon with the date of 1569 at f. 34v, at the end of the first text (Onasander's Strategicus, part I of the manuscript). Nevertheless, since the second text was written by Bergikios on the same kind of paper, as shown by the watermark, the same date, or a very near one, can be accepted for the copying of both texts. In any case, the second text cannot have been written after 1569: the scribe died in this year, and this manuscript is his last known dated work (see Dain 1949, p. 333).

As noted, parts II, III, V seem to be later additions. The watermark and the scripts of these leaves suggest that they originate in the second half of the 16th century. Part II is a quinion inserted in Onasander's text between two quires. It can be assumed that the text written by Bergikios was missing a part, probably due to the loss of a quire, and that this insertion was intended as a restoration. The scribe who copied this part (hand B), tried to adjust the insertion in Bergikios' text, but there are differences. The paper of the added quire is different, as are layout and script. The last word copied by hand B (f. 26v) is a repetition of the first word of the subsequent quire by Bergikios (f. 27r): the word has been underlined, probably in order to point out to the repetition, but maybe also in order to serve as a catchword for the insertion of the quire.

As regards parts III and V, both are single quires made up of the same paper used for the inserted part II. Therefore it is likely that they were added to the main part of the manuscript at the same time. The leaves were probably originally blank, inserted respectively, between the two main texts of the manuscripts (part III, ff. 35-38), and at the end of the manuscript (part V, ff. v-viii). On the 2nd leaf of part III (f. 36r), and on the 3rd of part V (f. vii recto) were written small excerpts, related to the theme of war of the main texts.

supportDesc.foliation:
Modern pencil foliation in Roman and Arabic numerals, in the upper right hand corner, recto: i-iv, 1-80, v-viii. The numbers i and viii have been attributed respectively to the left pastedown and to the
right pastedown.

collation.p: The first quire (1) is a binion formed by later endleaves; the first leaf is probably the left pastedown, f. i (reinforcing stripes have been placed in the gutter of ff. ii-iv , therefore it is now not possible to be certain of this.

condition.p: In fair condition. There are some humidity stains (see e.g. ff. 30r-58r in the upper margin) and spots on the leaves (see e.g. ff. 38v-39r). A few wormholes are visible in the upper right hand corner, see (see e.g. ff. 17r-37r). Large spots on the binding.

binding.p: Modern western binding, leather over millboard, spine with title and shelfmark tooled in gold. Blind tooling in form of a double frame on the boards. A leather label with authors' names tooled in gold is presently pasted on f. i.
binding.condition: Rebacked in 1969, as noted on f. ii recto: Repaired by Gray, Cambridge Oct. 1969.

additions.p: On the upper part of f. i are written an ownership note by Hautin and a title (see Provenance), and the manuscript's shelfmark.
Onf. iv verso an unknown hand wrote the title of the first work of the manuscript: Onosandri Strategica. Below, the same title is written by Hautin (see Provenance).

provenance.p: This manuscript was owned by by a certain J.B. Hautin, probably to be identified with Jean Baptiste II Hautin, son of the French scholar and numismatist Haultin, Jean-Baptiste, approximately 1580-1640 Jean-Baptiste Hautin (approximately b. 1580 d. 1640) (or possibly with his nephew Jean Baptiste III; on the problem of the identification of Hautin see Jackson 2006, pp. 38-40). : on f. i there is Hautin's ownership note, J. B. Hautin .

It was later owned by John Moore (b. 1646, d. 1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : number 995 in the handwritten supplementary list of Moore's manuscripts, now MS Oo.7.50(2), compiled by Thomas Tanner (1674-1735) after the publication of Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697). The number of the manuscript in Tanner's list is written on f. i, along with what looks like a shelfmark of unclear origin, also reported by Tanner: 995 (e. 4).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 . On f. i is glued the engraved bookplate made by John Pine for the Royal Library (1737).

recordHist.source: Description (2019) draws partly on A catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, vol. 3, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1858, pp. 700-701.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

analytic.title: The Greek Manuscripts of John Moore and Etienne Baluze

summary.seg: The first part of the manuscript contains Onasander's Strategicus, written by Angelos Bergikios in 1569 in Paris.

A part of the text, corresponding to a quire (ff. 17r-26v), was copied by another hand on another kind of paper (see part II): probably it is a later addition in order to fill a gap in the text, caused by the loss of a quire.

msItem.author: Onasander
msItem.title: Strategicus
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Ἱππικῶν μὲν λόγων, ἢ κυνηγετικῶν
msItem.note: ff. 17r-26v (W.A. Oldfather, A.S. Pease, and J.B. Titchener [eds.], Aeneas Tacticus, Asclepiodotus, Onasander, Cambridge, Mass. 1923 [repr. 1962], p. 444 line 3 [μεί]ζονι - p. 482 line 10 ἐπι[φαίνειν]) were copied by another hand on a different kind of paper, see part II
msItem.colophon: f. 34v ˏαφξθ΄, ἐν Λουτεκίᾳ τῶν Παρησίων Ἀγγέλου

support.material: ff. 1-16, 27-34 Western paper, folded in quarto, Watermark: Crown with three major and two minor arms surmounted by a six point star ( ca. 39 ca. 35 ) in the gutter comparable to Briquet Couronne à trois fleurons et deux demi 4835 and Harlfinger Krone 25-26 . The Briquet watermark is dated to 1561/1577 and comes from Italy. The Harlfinger watermarks Krone are dated respectively to 1561, 1562, and 1575.

signatures.p: Modern brown ink quire signatures in Roman letters, in the bottom right corner, recto, which have been mostly trimmed; they are visible at f. 1r (a), f. 9r (b), f. 27r (d).

supportDesc.condition: In good condition: the leaves are slightly yellowed near the edges, there are occasional wormholes on the upper right corner (e.g. ff. 27r-67r).

handNote.p: ff. 1r-16v, 27r-34v Hand A: the text has been written by Vergece, Ange, 1505-1569 Angelos Bergikios (Ἄγγελος Βεργίκιος, Angelus Vergetius) , (16th c., first quarter-1569) (RGK I, 3. See also RGK II, 3; RGK III, 3) in an accurate minuscule script, slanting slightly to the right.
The text is written in black ink; titles and initials in red.
The scribe also wrote corrections and additions in the margins, in black or red ink (see e.g. f. 12v), some have been trimmed (see e.g. f. 11v).

decoDesc.decoNote: Initials in ekthesis in red ink are decorated with a vegetal motif with pearls, see e.g. f. 9r.
Thick minor initials in red ink, see e.g. f. 13v.
Blank space was left at the beginning of the text, f. 1r, for the insertion of a bigger decorated inital.

p.note: At f. 34v, below the colophon, a later hand added in black ink Nicolaus Bergitius scripsit, and, in the left margin, 1569

additions.p: At f. 1r, in the upper margin, is written the manuscript shelfmark Kk-5-31.

origin.p: This part of the manuscript was written in 1569 by the Greek scribe Angelos Bergikios in Paris, as noted in the colophon.

summary.seg: Part II is an addition to the first text. Ff. 17r-26v form a quire, which was inserted between ff. 16 and 27, probably in order to supply a part of the text of Onasander's Strategicus, which was lost (probably a quire as well). The supplied part of the text was copied in Greek by a western European hand, which also added variants, glosses and corrections in the margins.

msItem.author: Onasander
msItem.title: Strategicus
msItem.incipit: f. 17r μείζονι χρώμενοι μεθ' οὓς οὐκ ἐπ' ἄλλοι τεταγμένοι
msItem.note: The text fills the lacuna of part I of the manuscript (Oldfather-Pease-Titchener 1923, p. 444 line 3 - p. 482 line 10).

support.material:
ff. 17-26 Western paper, folded in quarto, Watermark: Shield with letter
B
, not entirely visible, surmounted by a crown with a four-leaf clover; under the shield NICOLAS LE BE
( ca. 42 ca. 50 ) in the gutter. It is not possible to see the whole watermark, due to its position in the gutter. It is comparable to Sosower Lettre 3-4 which are dated to ca. 1567, and to Zonghi 2877-2878, which are dated to 1574.

collation.signatures: No signatures are visible in this quire.

supportDesc.condition: In good condition: the leaves are slightly yellowed near the edges, there are wormholes on the upper right corner at ff. 17-26.

handNote.p: ff. 17r-26v Hand B: informal minuscule, probably by a western European hand datable to the second half of the 16th c. The script is regular in size and forms, slanting slightly to the right, with thickenings at the ending of the strokes.
The text is written in grey ink, titles and initials in pale red.
The scribe wrote also corrections and additions in the margins, in the same ink of the text (see e.g. f. 17r) and in red (see e.g. f. 22v).

decoDesc.decoNote: Simple initials in ekthesis in red ink, see e.g. f. 18r.

history.origin: The watermark and the script suggest that Part II originates in the 2nd half of the 16th century, probably not long after the completion of Part I of the manuscript and the death of its scribe, Angelos Bergikios, both of which occurred in 1569.

summary.seg: Part III is a binion of the same paper as Part II, and was probably added to the manuscript at the same time, apparently in order to separate the two texts written by Bergikios. The four leaves were probably blank; another western hand wrote on f. 36r two extracts on tactics from Flavius Josephus.

msItem.author: Josephus, Flavius
msItem.title: Two excerpts from Jewish Antiquities, 7, 143
msItem.incipit: f. 36r Αριστον πάντων ἐν τῷ πολέμῳ πραχθέντων
msItem.explicit: f. 36r ὡς τὰ μὲν μιμεῖσθαι, τὰ δὲ φεύγειν

support.material:
35-38 Western paper, folded in quarto, Watermark: Shield with letter
B
, not entirely visible, surmounted by a crown with a four-leaf clover; under the shield NICOLAS LE BE
( ca. 42 ca. 50 ) in the gutter. It is not possible to see the whole watermark, due to its position in the gutter. It is comparable to Sosower Lettre 3-4 which are dated to ca. 1567, and to Zonghi 2877-2878, which are dated to 1574.

collation.signatures: No signatures are visible on this quire.

handNote.p: 36r Hand C: informal minuscule of the second half of the 16th century or the beginning of the 17th century. The script is small and regular in size. Spiritus are not regularly written (see the title).
Texts and title are written in brown ink.
The writing at f. 36r does not seem to be in the hand of Petros Bergikios as Jackson (2006, p. 33) suggested.

history.origin: The watermark suggests that part III originates, like part II, in the 2nd half of the 16th century, after 1569.

summary.seg: As in the case of part I, this part of the manuscript contains a text on military tactics, Aelian's Tactica, copied by Angelos Bergikios.

msItem.author: Aelianus, Tacticus, active 2nd century
msItem.note: ff. 71v-72r are blank, without loss of text

msItem.title: Prooemium
msItem.rubric: f. 39r Προοίμιον τῆς θεωρίας ταύτης, πρὸς τὸν αὐτοκράτορα Ἀδριανόν
msItem.incipit: f. 39r Τὴν παρὰ τοῖς Ἕλλησι τακτικὴν θεωρίαν, ἀπὸ τῶν Ὁμήρου χρόνων τὴν ἀρχὴν λαβοῦσαν, αὐτόκρατορ Καῖσαρ υἱὲ θεοῦ Ἀδριανέ σεβαστέ
msItem.explicit: f. 40r l. 12 τόπους ῥαδίως εὑρίσκων, τοὺς χρόνους μὴ τρίβῃς
msItem.note: In the manuscript the prooemium is addressed to the Emperor Hadrian

msItem.incipit: f. 40r l. 16 Περὶ τῶν συγγραφέων τῶν τὰ τακτικὰ καὶ στρατηγικὰ βιβλία συνταξαμένων, καὶ περὶ τῆς παρούσης βίβλου, ὅτι χρειωδέστατον τὸ μάθημα τοῦτο. Πρῶτος μὲν ὧν ἴσμεν, δοκεῖ τὴν τακτικὴν θεωρίαν Ὅμηρος
msItem.explicit: f. 79r καὶ τοῖς ἐναντίοις ἧτταν ἐπάγουσαι.
msItem.note: The paragraphs of the text are numbered in red ink from α΄ (1) to νγ΄ (53).

msItem.title: Εxplanation of a picture
msItem.incipit: f. 79v Λέγεται δ' αὕτη καὶ παρὰ τοῖς παλαιοῖς τετράπλευρος
msItem.note:
The picture referred to is not present in the manuscript. It is preserved in other manuscripts after Aelianus' text (see e.g.
Munich, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, Cod. Graec. 104 , f. 351r). The text of the explanation is edited by A. Köchly-W. Rüstow, Griechische Kriegsschriftsteller II: Die Taktiker, Leipzig 1855, pp. 552; see also A. Dain, Histoire du texte d'Élien le Tacticien des origines à la fin du Moyen Age, Paris 1946, pp. 156-157

support.material: 39r-80v Western paper, folded in quarto, Watermark: Crown with three major and two minor arms surmounted by a six point star ( ca. 39 ca. 35 ) in the gutter comparable to Briquet Couronne à trois fleurons et deux demi 4835 and Harlfinger Krone 25-26 . The Briquet watermark is dated to 1561/1577 and comes from Italy. The Harlfinger Krone watermarks are dated respectively to 1561, 1562, and 1575.

collation.p: Part IV consists of quaternions and a binion.
collation.signatures: Early quire signatures in Greek numerals by the hand of the scribe, in black ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower centre, original to the production of the manuscript, from α΄ (1, f. 39r) to ε΄(5, f. 71r).

handNote.p: 39r-80v Hand A: the text is written by Angelos Bergikios (Ἄγγελος Βεργίκιος, Angelus Vergetius, 16th c., first quarter-1569) (RGK I, 3) in black ink; titles and initials are in red.
The scribe also wrote corrections and additions in the margins, in black or red ink (see e.g. f. 40v), some have been trimmed.

decoDesc.decoNote: Initials in ekthesis in a red ink are decorated with a vegetal motif with pearls, see e.g. f. 43r
Minor initials written in a red ink see e.g. f. 78v.
Blanck space was left at the beginning of the text, f. 39r, for the addition of a bigger decorated inital.

Aelian's text is accompanied by illustrations, which represent formations and manoeuvres by means of simple small signs (circles, arrows...) and letters. They are traced by the scribe in black and red ink; circles have been colored sometimes in blue, green, red and gold (see e.g. ff. 44v-45r). They are present at
43r,
43v,
44v,
45r,
45v,
46v,
47v,
48r,
50v,
51r,
52r,
53r,
54r,
55r,
55v,
59v,
61r,
62v,
67r.

origin.p: This part of the manuscript, copied by Bergikios on the same kind of paper as part I, was in all probability written around the same year, 1569.

msIdentifier.idno: Part V, ff. v recto-vii verso

summary.seg: Part V is a binion composed of the same kind of paper found in parts II and III, therefore these leaves were probably added to the manuscript at the same time, in the second half of the 16th century, after 1569.

msItem.author: Philo Chronographus
msItem.title: Excerpt from De agricultura, 87-88
msItem.rubric: f. vii recto l. 1 Ἐκ τῶν Φίλωνος περὶ γεωργίας
msItem.incipit: f. vii recto l. 2 Τίνι γὰρ οὕτως λοχίσαι στρατεύματα, καὶ τάξαι
msItem.explicit: vii recto l. 7 τῆς ἐν τούτοις ἐπιστήμης περιουσίαν ἐξεγένετο
msItem.note: (ed. P. Wendland, Philonis Alexandrini opera quae supersunt 2, Berlin 1897 [repr. Berlin 1962], p. 112 lines 22-26)

support.material:
ff. v-vii Western paper, folded in quarto, Watermark: Shield with letter
B
, not entirely visible, surmounted by a crown with a four-leaf clover; under the shield NICOLAS LE BE
( ca. 42 ca. 50 ) in the gutter. It is not possible to see the whole watermark, due to its position in the gutter. It is comparable to Sosower Lettre 3-4 which are dated to ca. 1567, and to Zonghi 2877-2878, which are dated to 1574.

collation.p: Part V consists of 1 binion; the last leaf is probably the right pastedown, f. viii recto (reinforcing stripes have been placed in the gutter of ff. ii-iv, therefore it is now not possible to ascertain this.

handNote.p: f. vii recto Hand D: informal minuscule, rapid, characterized by a tendency to enhance the stems, of the 16th century or later.
Text and title are written in grey ink.

additions.p: There is a word in Greek on f. vii verso.

history.origin: The watermark suggests that part V originates, like parts II and III, in the 2nd half of the 16th century, after 1569.
